instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00430: What is 820-00430? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.820-00034: What is 820-00034? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00430</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power
threads.message:
So today I have on the healing bench and <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00430</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with no power. The first debug LED from the bottom is the "S5" LED. It comes on solid, then blinks a few times, goes off for a while, then blinks really fast a few times then goes out completely. So I gather it is not even in an S5 state. Here are the measurements from the S5 rails currently:

<SIGNAL>PP12V_S5</SIGNAL>: 2.2V
<SIGNAL>PP45V_S5</SIGNAL>: 0V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>: .7V

I am getting 12.15V on the 3 pins from the power supply, as well as the "G3Hot Rails"

Haven't worked on these really so I thought it would be educational to give it a try and see if I could solve it, with some assistance.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00430</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power
threads.message:
First check for short, or low value on diode mode on all power rails.

Which schematic ar you using?
Possibly leakage on <SIGNAL>12V_S5</SIGNAL> MOSFET; change it, for test.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00430</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power
threads.message: I am using the schematic for an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00034</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
